Narrator:
Let’s look at this more closely! You predicted that If the common belief were true, we would expect to see more alcoholism in those adults who had lived with parents who did not have alcoholism. However, if alcoholism runs in families because of being raised with a parent who has alcoholism, we would expect to see higher rates in those adults who had lived with parents who did have alcoholism, because of the influence of growing up in an environment where alcoholism was present. But guess what? The research indicated that as adults, the two groups of adoptees actually had the same rate of alcoholism. This tells us that alcoholism does not run in families because of the effect of being raised by a parent who has alcoholism. It also tells us that alcoholism can and does occur among people who have no family history of alcoholism. So, why does alcoholism run in families, then? To answer that, let’s look at the adoption research from a different direction.
